properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of snow and freezing rain is expected tonight through to Wednesday morning. Snow will develop this evening and may become heavy at times overnight, particularly on the east facing side of the Great Northern Peninsula. Snowfall accumulations of up to 15 cm are possible. South and east of White Bay, snowfall amounts will be much lower, as the precipitation is expected to change over to ice pellets or freezing rain. An extended period of freezing rain is possible on Tuesday as temperatures hover near zero. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-16T02:32:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T08:13:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1496114515.2019
Area: Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 5 to 10 millimetres of freezing rain is expected between tonight and Monday morning. Precipitation will begin as snow this evening before changing to freezing rain. Rain is then expected before changing back to snow Monday evening. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T11:18:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T02:19:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3977530526.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall continuing tonight. Total rainfall amounts of 15 to 30 mm are possible. The ground is still at least partially frozen over portions of Southern Ontario. As a result, the ground will have a limited ability to absorb this rainfall. Localized ponding in low-lying areas and on roads is possible. The rain will taper off from west to east overnight. Some snow is also possible overnight and early Monday morning, but any accumulation should be light. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T11:35:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T03:36:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0288767007.2019
Area: Uxbridge - Beaverton - Northern Durham Region, Kaladar - Bannockburn - Bon Echo Park, Fenelon Falls - Balsam Lake Park - Northern Kawartha Lakes, Apsley - Woodview - Northern Peterborough County, Lindsay - Southern Kawartha Lakes, Peterborough City - Lakefield - Southern Peterborough County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 5 cm of snow possible for Kootenay Pass tonight. A cool unstable airmass will persist over the BC Interior tonight giving a few flurries over most of the mountain passes. Over Kootenay Pass a more organized band of precipitation will move through late this evening producing up to 5 cm of snow accumulation. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T12:21:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T04:22:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1924647386.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall expected for Eastern Ontario. Rain at times heavy with embedded thunderstorms will continue tonight and become lighter Monday morning. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 mm are expected. With the ground being at least partially frozen across Eastern Ontario, this rainfall may lead to localized flooding in low-lying areas. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T18:36:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T02:37:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2312635912.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Active weather for early this week. Precipitation will begin as showers or flurries this evening. Over the northern Avalon, precipitation will change to an extended period of freezing rain or ice pellets later this evening before changing to rain early Tuesday morning. Over areas of the Northeast Coast, the showers or flurries will change to snow or ice pellets late this evening before transitioning to an extended period of freezing rain after midnight. The freezing rain is forecast to change to rain showers Tuesday morning. A freezing rain warning may be required with future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-15T16:08:37-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continuing tonight over higher elevation areas. Several hours of freezing rain are likely over areas of higher elevation before changing back to snow overnight into Monday morning. For lower elevation areas, temperatures will likely remain just above the freezing mark with 10 to 25 mm of rain possible before changing to snow overnight or Monday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T11:40:42-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system approaching the province from the west is forecast to cross New Brunswick this evening before moving into the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Tuesday. Rain over southern New Brunswick is expected to persist through the day and into the overnight hours tonight before changing to scattered flurries or showers Thursday morning as the low moves away. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are forecast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T15:43:43-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A messy mix of precipitation continuing tonight. Rain continues this evening over portions of Southern Ontario. Precipitation should change to snow overnight or early Monday morning with a few centimetres possible. There is also a risk of brief freezing rain. Motorists are advised to prepare for potentially hazardous travel conditions tonight. Precipitation will come to and end Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T11:31:42-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The snowfall warning has been ended for portions of Central Ontario, as snowfall amounts during the night were significantly less than first anticipated. However, snow has been intensifying somewhat early this morning. Some areas may see 4 to 8 cm this morning before the snow ends later this morning. Motorists are advised to exercise caution as poor travel conditions are likely this morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Active weather for early this week. Precipitation will begin as rain this afternoon and change to a wintry mix of snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain tonight. A prolonged period of freezing rain is possible overnight tonight, especially over higher terrain and along Route 430 from Deer Lake to Gros Morne National Park. Precipitation will change to showers or flurries on Tuesday. A freezing rain warning may be required for these areas with future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. A low pressure system approaching the province from the west is forecast to cross New Brunswick this evening before moving into the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Tuesday. Precipitation is expected to fall mainly as rain today. However, northernmost areas of the province could briefly see a mix of snow, ice pellets and freezing rain this morning. The rain will persist into this evening before changing to scattered flurries overnight tonight as the low pulls away. Rainfall amounts of 25 to 35 mm are forecast. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant late season snowfall overnight. Snow across central portions of Ontario has tapered off somewhat this evening. However, it should reintensify overnight. The snow will come to an end Monday morning. Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are likely by Monday morning. There will also be a risk of freezing rain in some areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. An extended period of snow, blowing snow, and strong winds is expected tonight through to Wednesday morning. Snow at times heavy will develop this evening and continue into Tuesday and Tuesday night. Total snowfall accumulations could exceed 30 cm in some areas by Wednesday morning. Strong northeasterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will accompany the snow and cause poor visibilities in blowing snow, especially on Tuesday and Tuesday night. The snow is expected to taper off by Wednesday morning but strong northerly winds will continue through the day on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-15T23:57:36-00:00

Area: Northern Peninsula East, Port Saunders and the Straits

Les SuÃªtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Strong easterly winds gusting to 80 km/h are forecast to develop in the Wreckhouse area this afternoon. Wind gusts will rapidly increase to near 130 km/h this evening. The winds are expected to diminish below warning criteria early Tuesday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A major spring storm will hit Eastern Quebec today and Tuesday. Precipitation will begin as snow this morning and change over to rain midday. Rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 millimetres are expected over these areas. A mixed bag of precipitation could produce ponding, wet accumulating snow or ice accretion on roads. Heavy rain may cause flash floods and flooding in low lying areas. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-16T00:58:59-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A major storm will hit the Lower North Shore beginning Monday evening and into Tuesday. 30 to 50 centimetres of heavy, wet snow are expected along with high winds and blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-16T00:37:54-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Between 10 and 25 centimetres of snow is expected over these areas by Tuesday morning. Snow will be heavy at times and may accumulate rapidly as a result. This accumulation of snow could result in broken tree limbs. The snow will become mixed with ice pellets and will change to rain during the day over parts of the GaspÃ© Peninsula. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
